perturbation.original_text:
DISTRIBUTOR will IMMEDIATELY report via telephone communication to Lucid any incidents that involve the use of PRODUCTS sold by the DISTRIBUTOR to end users that affect patient safety or well-being (an "INCIDENT"). Such oral incident reporting will be followed immediately by a written incident report that documents the detailed conditions that resulted in the INCIDENT and Distributor shall thereafter co-operate with Lucid in the investigation of any and all conditions that led to, or resulted from the INCIDENT.

B) DISTRIBUTOR will routinely, but not less than annually, report in writing to Lucid, documenting the end users to which PRODUCTS have been sold, including the address, telephone number and name of a person who is the primary emergency contact. Lucid will use this information in the event of Lucid issuing a product recall of the PRODUCT for safety or other reasons. If such an event occurs, and upon Lucid's request, the DISTRIBUTOR will immediately provide Lucid with the names, addresses, telephone numbers and emergency contact personnel of any end user sites not previously reported to Lucid.
perturbation.changed_text:
DISTRIBUTOR will report to Lucid any incidents that involve the use of PRODUCTS sold by the DISTRIBUTOR to end users (an "INCIDENT"). Distributor shall cooperate with Lucid in the investigation of any and all conditions that led to, or resulted from the INCIDENT.

B) DISTRIBUTOR will report to Lucid, documenting the end users to which PRODUCTS have been sold. Lucid will use this information in the event of Lucid issuing a product recall of the PRODUCT for safety or other reasons. If such an event occurs, and upon Lucid's request, the DISTRIBUTOR will provide Lucid with the names, addresses, telephone numbers and emergency contact personnel of any end user sites.
perturbation.explanation: The removal of the immediate reporting requirement for incidents affecting patient safety and well-being eliminates an essential safety measure and traceability requirement. By deleting 'via telephone communication', 'that affect patient safety or well-being', 'Such oral incident reporting will be followed immediately by a written incident report that documents the detailed conditions that resulted in the INCIDENT', 'routinely, but not less than annually', 'including the address, telephone number and name of a person who is the primary emergency contact' and 'not previously reported to Lucid' is a significant omission and creates a legal risk, as it weakens the manufacturer's ability to track products and respond quickly to safety concerns as required by FDA regulations for medical devices.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 21 CFR Part 821 - Medical Device Reporting; 21 U.S. Code ยง 360i - Records and reports on devices

perturbation.changed_text:
Lucid does not guarantee delivery of Product by any particular date. If Lucid accepts Distributor's order and fails to deliver ordered products, Distributors sole remedy will be limited to refund of money paid to Lucid for any undelivered products.

B) Lucid will not have any liability or responsibility to Distributor or any other person or entity for any consequential, indirect, special, punitive or incidental damages or lost profits, whether foreseeable or unforeseeable, based on claims of Distributor or Distributor's customers arising out of breach or failure of express or implied warranty, breach of contract, misrepresentation, negligence, strict liability in tort or otherwise. In no event will the aggregate liability incurred by Lucid in any action or  proceeding exceed the total amount actually paid to Lucid by Distributor for the purchase of the products that actually caused the damage or loss.
perturbation.explanation: By removing "(including but not limited to, claims for loss of data, goodwill, profits, use of money or use of product, interruption in use or availability of data stoppage or other work or impairment or assets), except only in the case of death or personal  injury where and to the extent that applicable law requires such liability" significantly broadens the liability waiver. The New York law generally does not allow companies to exclude liability for gross negligence or intentional misconduct. By removing the carve-out for death or personal injury the distributor is waiving all of its rights for this case. This is an attempt to eliminate any avenue for the distributor to recover damages, creating a legal risk of being unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: New York General Obligations Law ยง 5-321 - Agreements exempting lessors from liability for negligence are void and unenforceable
